He was just sitting in his own little world lost in his tunes pumping through the headphones. His back up against the cold metal beam of the waiting platform; waiting for the next train to burst through. Within moments a rush of air signals its arrival. Sliding in to the open slot next to the windows, he thought nothing of his familiar surroundings. It was the same trip and environment that he has been in so many days before. The train jerked to signal the start of the benign routine. The trains movements snapped his head and brought his eyes back up to stare out the crusty windows of the car. The eroding landscape of the city is played out before him like bits of corroded information. At points his visions and the music in his head collide and things make more sense for but a brief moment. As he is lost out the window something catches his eye. A reminder of the warmer weather; the appearance of the bare shoulder of the woman that has sat in front of him. Looking straight ahead

Cheb Balowski is a Spanish musical group of ten singers in Spanish, Catalan, and Arabic. They formed in Barcelona, 2000.
Apostle Paul has been the most intriguing figure after Jesus in the biblical scholarship since the early church. The numerous books have been written, dissertations have been published, and papers delivered. The interest has always been extremely high. A systematic, yet still occasional, way to describe the meaning of Jesus Christ death and resurrection is the main point found in the epistles of Paul. Many churchmen and scholars, confessing Christians and not, alike, have penned abundant number of articles, books, and dissertations in relation of Paul‚Äôs understanding of the Gospel of Jesus Christ.
What is Paul‚Äôs Gospel? For centuries, theologians had agreed that it could be described that sinners find God‚Äôs approval not by anything they do, but by God‚Äôs grace though faith in Christ‚Äôs substitionary atonement on their behalf on the cross.
Since the groundbreaking study of E.P. Sanders, Paul and Palestinian Judaism (1977), a traditional understanding of Pauline theology of salvation has been challenged by various writers and scholars. Sanders criticized that the ‚ÄúLutheran‚Äù understanding of first century Judaism was misguided and therefore, Luther, and all of those who had held the similar views of justification by faith alone, were wrong in their understanding of Paul and his view of what justification by faith mean. This new way to see Paul‚Äôs Gospel called, The New Perspective, claims that Paul did not merely talk about sinners being justified by faith alone in Christ, but mainly that Gentiles are included in the people of God by faith without the bother of becoming Jews.
In his book Perspectives Old and New on Paul: The "Lutheran" Paul and His Critics, Stephen Westerholm[1] defines the core understanding of the New Perspective and its claims, and then compares it to 1) the historic understanding of many theologians of the Christian church, and 2) to the Pauline texts themselves. Westerholm defines ‚ÄúLutheran‚Äù not by denominational structure or commitment, but by the readers, who consider Paul‚Äôs understanding of salvation to be the doctrine of justification by faith excluding any human ‚Äúworks‚Äù.
Westerholm defines the issue at stake well by paraphrasing: ‚ÄúWhether justification by faith, not by works of the law means ‚Äòsinners find God‚Äôs approval by grace, through faith, not by anything they do, or whether its thrust is that Gentiles are included in the people of God by faith without the bother if becoming Jews‚Äù (p. 445). According to Westerholm, the New Perspective emphasizes that Judaism was not ‚Äúlegalistic‚Äù in the first century. Jews did not think that they earned salvation; rather, God‚Äôs goodness was in their life because they had a covenant with God and they wanted to respond by fulfilling God‚Äôs covenant requirements.
The book can be divided into three parts. In part one, he describes the doctrine of Paul as proclaimed and written by Augustine, Martin Luther, John Calvin, and John Wesley. In part two, he briefly summarizes the responses of the scholars who question the traditional understanding of Paul‚Äôs Gospel and the Law. He also gives some counter-positions to these critics. In part three, he gives his own assessment of justification and law in Pauline texts.
The first part observes historical understanding of Paul‚Äôs soteriology. The choice of the historic theologians itself is quite interesting. Certainly, Augustine is a well-respected theologian in the Catholic Church. But he is also the master and pater of Protestant theology. Luther was an Augustinian monk and was well learned in Augustine writings. Similarly, John Calvin used Augustine more and more extensively as he edited the Institutes. Obviously, he grew to discover many doctrines from Augustine.
Where Augustine, Luther, and Calvin are well-respected theologians in the reformed-side of churches and scholarship, Wesley‚Äôs reputation is more questionable. This preacher, who proclaimed in different kinds of meetings many nights a week, and started ‚ÄúMethodist‚Äù groups in England, is of course well-known for his evangelistic fervor. However, his theology was more ‚Äúarminian‚Äù emphasizing the free will of a man. Whereas Augustine, Luther and Calvin spent considerable time refuting free-will people (Pelagius, Erasmus, Anabaptist), Wesley saw people having an ability to turn to Christ with their own. Despite of this drastic difference in soteriology, Westerholm wants to show, that their understanding of Paul and justification by faith is similar, if not identical. I suppose, Westerholm does this intentionally in order to show the more universal historic church position on the issue, within the larger scale of Christian church.
According to Westerholm there are at least seven fundamental similarities that these famous church theologians agree and what are the core issues of the Gospel in their theology (p.88-97).
1) Human nature, created good, has been so corrupted by sin that human beings are incapable of God-pleasing action. They are rightly subject to God‚Äôs condemnation.
2) Human beings must be justified by divine grace, responded to in faith, and not by any works of their own.
3) Justification by grace through faith leaves human beings with nothing of which they may boast in God‚Äôs presence. The false notion that human beings can contribute to their justification opens the door to a presumption that ill suits creatures in the presence of their Creator.
5) The Mosaic Law was given, in part, to awaken in human beings as awareness of their need of divine grace. Believers are delivered from its condemnation and need not observe its ceremonial prescriptions. The gift of God‚Äôs Spirit enables them (in some measure) to fulfill its moral demands.
6) Whether sin remains a reality in the lives of justified believers is an issue that ‚ÄúLutherans‚Äù cannot but confront, though they disagree in their assessment of it.
7) Whether the divine grace to which salvation is to be attributed must be deemed the irresistible source of the believer‚Äôs faith is an issue that ‚ÄúLutherans‚Äù cannot but confront, though they disagree in their assessment of it.
After the older assessment of these reformers, Westerholm moves to the 20th century critics of the Lutheran position. Westerholm gives a concise and well-understood summary of many exegetes contribution to the recent discussion in relations to Paul‚Äôs understanding of salvation. The developments of the critics are lead by E.P. Sanders and his influential book: Paul and Palestinian Judaism. According to Westerholm, Sanders wanted ‚Äúto destroy the view of Rabbinic Judaism which is still prevalent in much, perhaps most, New Testament scholarship‚Äù, namely, ‚Äúlegalistic works-righteousness.‚Äù Sanders emphasized the following things: application-orientation, God is faithful even Israel would disobey and no doctrine of original sin exists in Pauline theology ‚Äúdespite the tendency to disobey, man is free to obey or disobey.‚Äù Therefore, righteous is ‚Äúthe one who accepts the covenant and remains within it‚Äù and obedience is a ‚Äúcondition for remaining in the covenant, but they do not earn it‚Äù ‚Äì This what salvation by grace means. Sanders is trying to convey that Paul is not distinct from the rabbinic thinking ‚Äì except that salvation is eventually found in Christ. Thus: 1) The traditional Lutheran view, namely, the doctrine of justification, not by works (rabbinic thought) is wrong. 2) Doctrine of justification is correct in that it is not by works. It is Paul, who misinterpreted the Judaism, the faith of his fathers.
Another significant study that has lead to the rise of New Perspective is Kummel‚Äôs work on Paul. Westerholms describes well Kummel‚Äôs argumentation on the identity of ŒµŒ≥œâ in Romans 7. Kummel is the first modern scholar who argues for non-Pauline identity of ŒµŒ≥œâ in Romans 7. Since that many scholars have considered this as a norm in scholarship and followed Kummel‚Äôs argumentation (see Appendix 2 for argumentation).
Following Kummel, Krister Standahl (The Apostle Paul and the Intropective Conscience of the West, 1972) has tried to persuade that Paul cannot talk about himself in Romans 7. The consciousness of Paul prior to conversion was not sin struggling. He did not seem to have a personal problem as have been suggested based on Phil 3, 1 Cor. 4:4, 2 Cor. 12:7; Gal 4:13. Therefore, the problem of Lutheran Paul discussion ‚ÄúHow can I find a gracious God‚Äù is not a Pauline question. So Christians have asked the wrong question.
I do not find Kummel‚Äôs argument fully compelling since Paul did not have a sinful understanding of himself prior to his conversion. Therefore, he can say that he was ‚Äúblameless when it comes to law‚Äù. This does not prove is sinlessness, but his self-righteousness.
Then Westerholm discusses other noteworthy scholars and their input the conversation. For example: Wrede says that justification is a ‚Äúpolemical doctrine‚Äù where Schweiter states that ‚ÄúThe doctrine of righteousness by faith is therefore a subsidiary crater, which has formed within the rim of the main crater ‚Äì mystical doctrine of redemption through the being-in-Christ.
Next, Westerholm discusses the understanding of ‚Äúthe righteousness of the law‚Äù in current scholarship showing by numerous examples that there is no scholarly consensus on Paul‚Äôs view of the law. For Rudolf Bultmann ‚Äúrighteousness of the Law‚Äù is ‚Äùbad‚Äù because it is based on Jewish self-focused recognition on his own accomplishments. Opposite to Bultmann, Ulrich Wilckens, righteousness of the Law is ‚Äùgood‚Äù because the law was positive to Jews but they failed to keep it. For E.P. Sanders ‚Äúrighteousness of law‚Äù is indifferent because he claims quite uncaringly ‚Äùthe supposed objection to Jewish self-righteousness is as absent from Paul‚Äôs letters as self-righteousness itself is from Jewish literature‚Äù (Law, 156).
John W. Drane thinks Paul‚Äôs thinking changed between Galatians and Romans. Paul was a ‚Äùlibertinist‚Äù in Galatians and ‚Äùlegalist‚Äù in 1 Corinthians, but more balanced in 2 Corinthians and in Romans. Hans Hubner saw Galatians view on law negative, but in Romans a positive view on law. The change happened because of the Jerusalem apostles. Heikki R√§is√§nen says that Paul‚Äôs view on law was not consistent even in Romans: ‚Äùcontradictions and tensions have to be accepted as constant features of Paul‚Äôs theology of the law‚Äù (Law, 11). He says that Paul‚Äôs personal theological problem required ‚Äùa historical and psychological explanation‚Äù (12). According to R√§is√§nen, Paul is trying to defend impossible situation, namely ‚Äùthat a divine institution has been abolished through what God has done in Christ Unanswerable, yet real Pauline statement: Christians dispense the law that they believe is from a divine origin.‚Äù (264-265). Kuula follows R√§is√§nen by saying that Paul is trying to defend this with forced interpretations of the Scripture and artificial arguments.
Next, Westerholm moves to the other New Perspective advocates. These scholars do not question as much Paul‚Äôs consistency. Unlike the scholars mentioned above, who say that Paul missed the point, these scholars say that Luther missed the point. The 1st century Judaism was not righteous by works oriented.
James D.G. Dunn (Jesus, Paul and the Law, 1990; Theology of Paul the Apostle, 1998), another energetic defender and the person who coined the New Perspective says: ‚ÄùJudaism is first and foremost a religion of grace.‚Äù For Dunn, the works of the law does not mean that good works would gain salvation. Rather, they mean ‚Äúboundary markers‚Äù (e.g. circumcision, Sabbath, food laws, cleanness laws) that marked out the Jews as God‚Äôs covenant people. He does not consider justification as an act of legal pronouncement by God, but as an ongoing process done by God.
One of the clearest advocates of the New Perspective, N.T. Wright (The Climax of the Covenant, 1991; Christian Origins and the Question of God, 1992-), has become one of the most influential NT scholars of today. He says that the core of Pauls‚Äôs Gospel was not justification, but Jesus death, resurrection and exaltation as Lord. claims that for Paul God‚Äôs righteousness, namely, covenant faithfulness, was climactically at work in Jesus (‚ÄùThe real Judaism was not a religion or legalistic works-righteousness‚Äù, rather it was ‚Äùbased on a clear understanding of grace‚Äù (History, 79-80). Justification means primaraly that all who have faith in Jesus belong as full member of God‚Äôs family.
C.E.B. Cranfield, an eminent British scholar, follows the reformed understanding of the law that is in the perfect harmony of the Gospel (though the term is used only an aspect of it).
Thomas Schreiner, an American Pauline scholar, holds the Reformed understanding of the law. Even though his arguments are based on same material as Sanders‚Äô, the conclusions are different. The difference between Lutheran and Reformed understanding of the law is that the Lutherans stress the discontinuity between the Old and New covenant, while for the Reformed ‚Äùthe two covenants are basically continues in principle, but recognize the difference in salvation history‚Äù and therefore a regenerate person can obey the law.
Mark Seifrid, one of the staunchest critics of the New Perspective, has written a lot about the topic. He argues that in Adam we are all sinners, in Christ we are righteous. Not simply to provide additional justification but full justification (read=Justification by faith alone).
Westerholm also mentiones other perspectives to consider including two Finnish scholars, Timo Laato and Lauri Thuren. According to Laato, the greatest weakness of Sanders‚Äô argumentation is his inadequate coverage of the question of the capacity of humankind. Humanity is in ‚Äúwretched state of calamity‚Äù and therefore no one can do right from pure motives. Jewish understanding is based on human free will; Pauline anthropology is in the state of depravity.
Lauri Thuren focuses on Paul‚Äôs rhetoric and how we cannot read Paul as static way but understand that he was trying to affect his readers. An ancient Judaism was more diverse than Sanders portrays.
According to Westerholm, Sanders claims that Paul and Palestinian Judaism did not distinguish between grace and works. Getting in is by grace and staying in is by works. Sanders says that protestant view that Judaism was to get saved by works is misguided because Israel was elected to be the covenant community by ‚Äúcovenant nomism‚Äù, that is divine grace. Westerholm however, argues against it that the historic texts do not speak for it. Moreover, many old Pauline scholars are frustrated with Sanders because he seems to portray Judaism as Pelagius type religion, where humans are not totally depraved.
In the third part of his book, Westerholm discusses with the Pauline texts. He goes through all the Pauline texts in the light of explicit and implicit justification language.
¬∑ The law us understood to prescribe what people ought to do, and those who behave accordingly are dikaios
¬∑ Righteousness is what sinners need and lack. Gentile do not lack it by definition (because they are not part of the covenant) only because people are sinners
¬∑ It is Judaism that links dikaio terminology with a process of outsiders coming to belong to God‚Äôs people.
1. Thessalonians. Nothing gives evidence that Paul would have considered that loyalty to Jewish covenant provided a option for salvation. It is true that ‚Äújustification by faith‚Äù term does not occur. However, the concept is seen here as the reformers articulated it: faith itself works. The Paul of Thessalonians says nothing to offend his ‚ÄúLutheran‚Äù readers, but neither does he articulate a distinctively ‚ÄúLutheran‚Äù position.
